<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 378, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/32  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 264, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Theory (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 213, 617]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the distance–time graph for a student's journey.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 98, 897, 435]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 444, 551, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 473, 660, 494]]<|/det|>
The student walks from his home to a shop. He stops at the shop.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 489, 670, 510]]<|/det|>
Then he walks to his friend's house and stops there for 50 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 504, 531, 524]]<|/det|>
Then he walks back to his home without stopping.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 146, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 536, 180, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 536, 816, 556]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance between the student's home and his friend's house.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 581, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 181, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 613, 724, 633]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance between the shop and the friend's house.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 660, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 691, 148, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 691, 615, 710]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total time for which the student is walking.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 768, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>time = .................................................... min [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 800, 146, 819]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 800, 789, 819]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average speed of the student when he walks back to his home.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 876, 920, 896]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... m/s [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 907, 920, 926]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student wants to measure the diameter of a wire. The wire is thinner than a single gradation on her ruler. She coils the wire carefully and makes 12 loops as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 114, 751, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 317, 532, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 146, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 851, 381]]<|/det|>
Describe how she can use her ruler to determine the diameter of the wire accurately. You may draw on Fig. 2.1 as part of your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 488, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 146, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 517, 645, 536]]<|/det|>
The student determines the density of the metal of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 533, 707, 551]]<|/det|>
She folds some of the wire into a small shape as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 560, 675, 618]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 634, 532, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 664, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
She then puts this small shape of wire into a measuring cylinder containing water. The measuring cylinder is on an electric balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 711, 452, 730]]<|/det|>
This procedure is shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 71, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A car has a fault. A mechanic uses a machine to pull the car onto a recovery vehicle as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[138, 112, 856, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 336, 534, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 368, 146, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 368, 809, 387]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.2 shows how the mechanic applies a force to the handle of the machine.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 395, 710, 585]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 599, 534, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 183, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 631, 907, 650]]<|/det|>
Calculate the moment of the \(26\mathrm{N}\) force about the pivot. Use the information in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 753, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<form>moment = ............................................... $Nm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 785, 180, 803]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 920, 819]]<|/det|>
Describe **one** way the mechanic can increase the moment of the \(26\mathrm{N}\) force about the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 828, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 813, 88]]<|/det|>
The car is lifted vertically \(0.78 \text{m}\) onto the recovery vehicle, as shown in Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 96, 792, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 252, 534, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 284, 430, 301]]<|/det|>
The weight of the car is 14 000 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 298, 920, 333]]<|/det|>
Calculate the minimum work done on the car in lifting it onto the recovery vehicle from the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 330, 290, 346]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 498, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
<form>work done = ................................... unit .............. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 530, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Energy stored in the water behind hydroelectric dams is an example of a renewable energy source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 180, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 114, 620, 134]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by a renewable energy source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 172, 181, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 170, 653, 190]]<|/det|>
State the name of one other renewable energy source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 201, 920, 219]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 231, 148, 249]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 231, 712, 249]]<|/det|>
Electrical power is generated from the energy store in nuclear fuels.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 246, 860, 265]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows an energy flow diagram for transferring energy from the nuclear store.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 271, 865, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 508, 534, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 510, 555]]<|/det|>
Using the information in Fig. 4.1, calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 180, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 566, 772, 585]]<|/det|>
the percentage of energy wasted to thermal and kinetic energy stores

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<form>energy wasted = ............................................ % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 666, 181, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 666, 675, 684]]<|/det|>
the percentage of energy transferred as electrical working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 737, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<form>electrical working = ............................................ % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 766, 146, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 766, 787, 785]]<|/det|>
Electrical power is also generated from the water behind hydroelectric dams.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 796, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
State **two disadvantages** of generating electricity from the water behind hydroelectric dams compared with using the energy store in nuclear fuels. Ignore costs of construction and maintenance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 854, 917, 873]]<|/det|>
1 ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 883, 917, 902]]<|/det|>
2 ....................................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 897, 920, 916]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Fig. 6.1 shows a wood burner in a cabin. The wood burner keeps the inside of the cabin warm when it is cold outside.

<mark>[a]

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 833, 420]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 416, 888, 435]]<|/det|>
Use your ideas about the density of air. You may draw on Fig. 6.1 as part of your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 572, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
